snippet.textDisplay: I just found your channel n m glad n more than happy 😀.. my question is that researchers have been studying proteins in diff species,then how come coronavirus came to existence all of a sudden with its structure unknown, is it a result of mutation?👍👍
snippet.textOriginal: I just found your channel n m glad n more than happy 😀.. my question is that researchers have been studying proteins in diff species,then how come coronavirus came to existence all of a sudden with its structure unknown, is it a result of mutation?👍👍

snippet.textDisplay:
@CompilingInput that is evolution. Our DNA (or RNA in the case of SARS-Co2) is mutating all the time. We are interacting with the world around us, and this energy leaves changes in our genes. Some of the changes have no effect at all to the outside and others do (think of cancerous tissues). While these changes could be lethal under certain conditions it can also lead to evolutionary advantages increasing ur survival. For example if a protein in ur body mutates and this would lead to a insensitivity to   higher co2 levels in the air. And the co2 would rise to a level where everyone else would die, than this helped you survive and this gene will be propagated through next generations.
With the virus its the same. The virus might have mutated multiple times leading to less infective versions or versions where stability is so bad that it couldn't assemble at all. But these of course would not end up being investigated by us ;) was this helpful? did i explain it clearly? 😄

snippet.textDisplay: @Hussain Biology wow, that is so divine, but how come virus mutates, i mean how they know what to do to adapt n from where are they getting the info to mutate n how they r getting info of host n then how they find the loophole???. Sry for naive questions but  all these new concepts r creating lots n lots of questions in my minds.thanks for responding n yer time 👍

snippet.textDisplay:
the beauty of Virus is that when it jumps from one species to other ( called Cross species jump ) it mutates in way that mode of entry is adapted for the host cell.
So a hypermutation in viruses causes the outbreak of new strains.
Sometimes we are forced to think upon are viruses evolved more than us when it comes to their survival since they always change for their survival.
